I have been right down the Katherine River towards the Western Australian border and I know something of the conditions under which those people operate. I know something of the difficulties confronting Alice Springs. I know something of the water problem at Tennant Creek and 1 am glad to learn that that problem is being tackled with enthusiasm.

Tennant Creek, which was supposed to be a mining town with a life of a few years, now has a reasonable expectation of existence, lt will not close down in ten years or twenty years; it may have 50 years dr 100 years life before it. There was a time when it was thought that Broken Hill would be worked out in 50 years from some time around the 1880's. The latest expectation is that Broken Hill will last probably another 50 or 60 years, or even longer. I suppose the honorable member for Forrest (Mr. Freeth) who is listening with great interest to what I am saying to-night, would know the dismalprophesies that were made as to the future of Collie, in his electorate.

All mining towns live precariously, but tremendous resources are available in the Northern Territory. The geological structure makes that so. All the rest of Australia south of the Katherine River, with few exceptions, is of a very late geological age, but the Northern Territory, extending through Arnhem Land into the Cloncurry belt and Mount Isa in Queensland, with its valuable deposits of copper and where the Mary Kathleen strike has made so many people rich from the sale of uranium and will do so much for Queensland, is preCambrian or Devonian rock and is so old that it has become mineralized. A lot of mineral wealth will be found in that area in the future. There are other areas, but none so rich as this area.

We have every reason to be grateful to the people who are attacking the problem of this frontier for us. We should give them all the help that we can. Any money spent on the Northern Territory, Papua or New Guinea is money well spent as a premium on an insurance policy on the continued existence of this nation. 1 wish the Government well in its efforts to do all that it can as quickly as possible, because time is against us. I should like all members who can do so to go to the Northern Territory and northern Australia, and I should like them to go at different times of the year. I can assure them that wherever they go, up and down the main road or away from the beaten tracks, whether they are out at Wyndham in the west or at Bulman, in Arnhem Land, there will always be Australians anxious to meet them as members of the National Parliament, to co-operate with them and give them all the assistance they can, to help them to inform their minds on all that is good to be seen and all that can be done for the further development of this last frontier that western civilization has to cross.

talk.start.para: . - I had not thought to speak in this debate, but after listening to the honorable member for Bradfield (Mr. Turner), whose closing sentences reminded me of the more vigorous speeches of the honorable member for East Sydney (Mr. Ward), I feel that there are a few things that could be said and perhaps should be said. There is no easy or quick road to development of the pastoral areas of the Northern Territory. There are immense problems and immense difficulties that are peculiar to that area and to that area alone. There are three main districts in the Northern Territory, and each has its own problems: Alice Springs, the north-west, and the Barkly Tableland. Perhaps the best district, from one point of view, is that round Alice Springs, because there the small settlers have been extremely successful. They can not only breed their cattle but they can also fatten them to a large extent, and they have the railway to take them down to the markets in Adelaide. In the northwest the country is far more difficult to cultivate and the result on the whole is nothing like so good, and there are immense problems with disease and other things.

speech.para: The Barkly Tableland is the area to which I wish to devote my remarks chiefly tonight, mainly in an effort to dispel some of the impressions that the honorable member for Bradifeld may have left with honorable members. The Barkly Tableland is breeding country and nothing but breeding country. One cannot fatten cattle on the tableland. It is an immense distance from markets. It does not matter in what direction one goes, whether to Brisbane or to Adelaide, the distance is immense. There one cannot make fodder reserves for times of drought, as is done in Victoria, New South Wales, or any of the closely settled areas. Fodder reserves must be on the ground. Hay cannot be cut and put in sheds. It is not a practical proposition to do that for large numbers of cattle. Very little can be done on the tableland to improve the quality of the grasses. I think it is recognized throughout the north of the Territory and Queensland that Mitchell and Flinders grasses together make some of the best and most nutritive grasses for cattle or sheep in the respective areas. The tableland is almost unique in having no permanent natural water whatsoever. There are water holes, it is true, bat they cannot be relied upon, and any permanent water must come from the efforts of the men who graze the land. At the present time it costs between £4,000 and £5,000 to put down a bore that will water up to 500 cattle, and quite a big sum would have to be spent to water a large number of cattle. One cannot irrigate, as the bore water, together with the little rain water, is barely sufficient to keep the gardens going round the homestead. Unless in the future there is some vast and imaginative scheme to get fresh water to that area, irrigation must be ruled out.

The honorable member for Bradfield criticized this area, and perhaps his criticizm would have been a little more just if, instead of sleeping under the stars, as he claimed to have done, he had accepted the hospitality of many of its people. Then he would have learned of their troubles and difficulties, and of their efforts to overcome these problems. He said that there were no fences in the urea and contended that that was a point against people on the tableland, but fences are not necessary when there is no water to which cattle can wander. They are taken to a bore. They feed around the bore and come back to it every couple of days for a drink. They cannot go away because they know of no other water. On good properties bores are located about 15 miles apart. The cattle can walk 6i miles out and 64 miles back to a bore, but they cannot walk from one bore to another unless they are driven. The country is grazed by moving herds from ons: bore to another round the various properties. On large properties - this is not possible on small one - reserves of feed for times of drought are provided by having unstocked or unused pastures available for use. Those on small properties cannot do this on anything like the same scale, because in order to make an adequate return they attempt to stock the whole property all the year round in good seasons, and when the inevitable drought comes, as it did with great damage in 1952, the Mitchell grasses are eaten out. These are perennial grasses which, once eaten out, take many years of good seasons to come back.

There are many other difficulties in the Territory which are peculiar to it. For instance, if a new bull is imported from Queensland or New South Wales, he must be kept in a small paddock for about two years before being put out in the herd, not because he is too young but because he must become acclimatized to the Northern Territory. He must learn to walk and his feet must harden. After two years one can put him out and get some use from him. Just under £10,000 was spent last year in subsidizing the transport of good stud bulls from Queensland and New South Wales to the Barkly Tableland and to the Northern Territory as a whole. If stock is lost as a result of drought, it must be bred up again. Replacements cannot be bought anywhere in Australia. Shorthorns of the Northern Territory are not like the shorthorns in Victoria or New South Wales. They are cattle of a type which is suitable to the Territory and acclimatized to it, and calves bought from New South Wales and Victoria would find it very difficult to exist in the conditions that prevail there. The effect of all these characteristics operates inevitably against small properties. First, for a grazing property to be successful it should be able to breed and to fatten and then sell to the market, but on the tableland one can only breed. The large properties of companies are run in conjunction with fattening properties in Queensland. The companies shift their cattle to Queensland, fatten them, and sell them to the markets. Many properties on the tableland before the last war and before fattening properties were bought, could not be run at a profit when used merely for breeding and selling stores. In times of drought the small settlers find it very difficult to have adequate reserves of feed. At such times big properties can afford to spend £4,000 or £5,000 in putting down an extra bore. Indeed, I have been told that one property alone in the 1952 drought spent £ 60,000 in putting down new bores so that its cattle might be pastured on areas that would otherwise not have been opened up and on which the grasses were not of particularly good quality.

Companies operating tableland properties have done a great job in introducing new blood into their herds. Brunette Downs, Alroy, Lake Nash, Alexandria and Avon Downs produce some of the best cattle known to Queensland and the rest of the north. They introduce a great deal of new blood. Some of these companies buy from 100 to 200 new bulls a year. They are not, as the honorable member for Bradfield said, using scrub bulls or mickies to keep up the numbers of the herds. In the tableland area, at least, that is not done on the great majority of stations. Perhaps proof that cattle from the area are good and can be good, and can compete with cattle from any other part of Australia, is afforded by the fact that, three years ago, one company sold 6,000 head of cattle of an average killed weight of 913 lb. to a fattening property in Queensland. Their average age was about four and a quarter years. This was older than we like to see them in the south, but they were good cattle and killed well. You cannot do that if you are using scrub bulls and not keeping up the quality of your herds. Another company has spent great sums of money upon developing a transport system that is particularly suited to those areas. The company bought large British transports and trailers, which had been designed to its own specifications. It now transports cattle to the rail head and estimates that it saves one hundred pounds of meat on every animal during the 100-mile trip. An indication of the difficulty of this enterprise is given by the fact that when the road train began to operate not one truck trailer link could stand up to the stress caused by the roads over which the vehicles had to travel. Indeed, in some areas there were no roads at all and fully equipped workshops and machine shops had to be set up on the properties in the very far west of Queensland so that the transports might be kept moving.

The honorable member for Bradfield (Mr. Turner) compared the territory properties with the King Ranch, but I do not believe that it was a fair comparison. One million acres on the King Ranch do what it takes 7,000,000 acres on the Barkly

Tableland to do. Also, there are 600 oil wells on the King Ranch, which earn a dollar a minute for their operators. The owners of the ranch may only get royalties upon those dollars but a calculation will show that, even without cattle, they are millionaires. Revenue from the oil wells made it possible for the Klebergs to spend enormous sums of money in experimentation and they finally produced the " Monkey ", a mixture of the Brahmin and Shorthorn blood, which has been the foundation of the Santa Gertrudis herd. The introduction of these cattle may have extremely beneficial results in some of the more diseased and difficult buffalo and ticky areas of the far north. It is not realistic to compare the King Ranch, with its oil wells, and the immensely difficult and different conditions of the Barkly Tableland.

The Government's attitude to these problems of the Northern Territory, especially in regard to pastoral leases, has been realistic, and the Minister is to be praised for his efforts to achieve improvements. As I understand it, the objective of the Government has been greater production. There is no justification for any landholder having land which he does not use, but when a holding, whether large or small, is producing to capacity and is not being spoilt by erosion or over-stocking, the pastoralist is doing a good job for Australia and should not be taken to task. I have tried to show that the peculiar and individual conditions of the Barkly Tableland load the dice heavily against the small man. Indeed, in that part of the world anyone who has only £50,000 or £60,000 invested is regarded as a small man and it is thought that one would be stupid to breed cattle there unless one had at least that much money to spend. Therefore, when we speak of small or large land-holders, we must realize that in those areas the words have a very different meaning from that given them in the more closely settled areas of Victoria, New South Wales or South Australia.

From what I have said to-night it might be thought that I am opposed to closer settlement, or the breaking up of large areas. This is by no means the case. In Victoria I have consistently supported soldier settlement, but it is no use putting people onto small areas when they will not succeed because the land should really be held in large blocks only. The pastoral areas of the Northern Territory, as in the past, will in the future be best managed by large companies, lt is true that absentee owners, especially overseas owners, have not done what they should have done, and have let some properties, chiefly in the north-west, go to the pack. To prevent or minimize this, stricter leases might perhaps be granted in the future, but I could not support the suggestion of the honorable member for Bradfield that the Government should break existing contracts with leaseholders so that areas may be cut up more quickly. If a person with a ten, fifteen or twenty year lease comes to the Government and says, " If you will give me a longer lease, I will be happy to see some of the land set aside for closer settlement," it is a different matter, and I believe that on such occasions stricter terms are written into leasehold contracts. But there should certainly not be any compulsion in this matter. That is not something that we in the Liberal party should support.

The Government's policy for improving the production of the pastoral areas of the Northern Territory has, I believe, been very wise. Some of the tableland properties are experimenting in the hope of getting their cattle to the markets at two and a half years instead of four years. When this can be done the quantity of quality beef production in Australia will rise tremendously.
Debate (on motion by Mr. Costa) adjourned.

debate.para: Flood Relief - Department of Works' Contracts - Import Licensing - Timber - Television Sets.
Motion (by Sir Eric Harrison) proposed -

quote.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: . - I want to take up only a few minutes of the adjournment debate, but I think that it is necessary because this afternoon 1 could not get an opportunity to place a few facts before the House in connexion with the Army's part in alleviating the effects of the tragic Murray River flood. The Minister for the Interior (Mr. Fairhall) stressed this afternoon that the matter was, constitutionally, one for the States only, but the Common wealth Government has always recognized the national implications of such disasters. It has always been prompt and generous in its subsidy, but I want to point out that in addition, whenever these tragedies have occurred, it has always rendered major help through its defence forces. As was mentioned this afternoon, the Navy and the Air Force have played their part. I shall have a word or two to say about the Air Force later.

speech.para: I do not think that the people of Australia appreciate the extent to which the Army has responded to the call during this and previous floods. Our floods appear to be growing worse and worse as the years go by. We have already had disasters in New South Wales, Queensland and Victoria and now the devastating Murray River flood has occurred. There have been many minor floods in Australia that have affected considerable numbers of people but have not been so widespread as other floods; but in every flood, major or minor, in Australia in recent years, the Army has been called upon to help, and has responded nobly. So, apart altogether from the particular flood under discussion, the Army has actually spent hundreds of thousands of pounds in New South Wales, Queensland and Victoria in rendering assistance in major and minor floods.

During the present Murray River flood, the Army has had 550 men engaged in flood relief work in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia, and has used equipment worth £150,000. To give honorable members some idea of some of the equipment being used for that purpose I need only mention that Army personnel used a 40-ft. Bailey bridge in South Australia, a number of bulldozers, ducks, trucks, front-end loaders, portable cookers, tents, Army emergency telephones, blankets, stretchers, cutlery, and no fewer than 75,000 sand bags. The cost, to the. Army, of all this assistance, is no less than £200,000, which is the Army's contribution in cash to relief in the Murray River floods. That assistance and that contribution are still going on. The Army is still helping in that flood.

I have given those figures to show the extent to which the Army has given help. I know that everybody who knows the facts and understands them has eulogized the work of the Army in this respect, and it appears possible that if the floods do not soon abate the Army will be involved in an expenditure of £250,000. That is a lot of money for the Army to provide from its own budget. There is a former Minister for the Army, the honorable member for Adelaide (Mr. Chambers), now seated on the Opposition . front bench, who understands what this means. The money expended by the Army on assistance during floods is outright Army expenditure. It is not refunded to the Army. There is a feeling growing in the country that, whatever happens, the Army can be called upon to help. Such help, however, is not given without some sacrifice by the people who do the necessary work, because they are called upon to work for long hours and under great inconveniences. I think that the admiration of every one in Australia should be extended to those men of the Army who are prepared to come forward and do the great and necessary work of relief in the event of a national disaster, as in this case. It is because of that I have risen to say thanks, on behalf of the Government and the people of Australia, to the men of the Army who have done such magnificent work. Those people who have seen the results of that work will, I think, endorse everything that I have said.

I wish now to comment on a statement made this afternoon by the honorable member for Darling (Mr. Clark) about the Air Force. I do so in order to have the record put straight. The honorable member for Darling charged the Air Force with not giving much help to flood-stricken people and, from what I gathered from his remarks, had charged certain excessive amounts for help.

talk.start.para: - He did not say they were excessive.

- The suggestion that the honorable member for Darling made is quite wrong. The facts are that a special aircraft was made available by the Air Force, free of charge, to General Dougherty who is the man in charge of this kind of work in New South Wales. It was made available at no cost to New South Wales, to do whatever was required to be done under the control of General Dougherty. In addition to that, as the New South Wales Government was unable to -get private aircraft to carry out the work of dropping fodder to farmers and graziers, but was willing to hire such aircraft, that Government entered into an arrangement with the Air Force to hire certain aircraft at a very nominal fee, which was only the actual expense of running the aircraft. The Air Force managed that transaction for the New South Wales Government, but had nothing to do with any charges imposed on farmers or graziers in regard to the dropping of fodder. The charges made were made by the New South Wales Government and not by the Air Force or the Commonwealth.
- That is not true!
- That is my advice.
- Did they not get only one aircraft notwithstanding the fact that they asked for more?

- No, the position was that the Air Force supplied such aircraft as it could supply under that arrangement with the New South Wales Government, and the New South Wales Government used them and paid the running costs, which were quite nominal. New South Wales made certain charges to certain farmers and graziers in connexion with the matter. I wished to make that clear, because it has been the policy of all the defence forces of Australia - Navy, Army and Air - to go to the help of the people when help is needed, and I should not like the idea to get abroad among the people that any one of the arms of the defence forces was not prepared to give of its best in the interests of the people when assistance was needed in tragedies of the kind that we have been discussing.

speech.para: My prime purpose in rising, of course, was to give the figures that I have given in relation to the Army's contribution to assistance during floods, and to say a word of thanks to the officers and men of the Army who did such magnificent work in alleviating the pain and tribulation that people have suffered in such national disasters.

talk.start.para: .- Before I discuss the matter that I rose particularly to mention, I wish to refer to some of the remarks made by the Minister for the Army (Mr. Cramer) in respect of the speech of my colleague the honorable member for Darling (Mr. Clark). I suggest to the Minister that he be more carefully briefed before he comes into the House to make such allegations as he has made to-night. The facts, which are very well known and are easily available if any inquiry is made, are that, in the first instance, one Royal Australian Air Force plane that was made available to drop fodder into the flood devastated areas in a particular part of New South Wales, was made available as the result of negotiations between the honorable member for Gwydir (Mr. Ian Allan)" and the Minister for Air (Mr. Townley). The arrangement was that the fodder was to be dropped on to the properties of particular graziers in difficulties. lt was only after a number of smaller men, who were also affected by the floods, began to protest through their Parliamentary representatives, who approached the Treasurer, that this airlift was extended. Graziers in the Moree district, operating in a big way, got their fodder dropped in at no cost to them whatever. What the honorable member for Darling was expressing objection to, and quite rightly, was that some of the smaller men who were then afforded some assistance in respect to the dropping of fodder had what are, in my opinion, excessive charges levied on them in respect of the use of Royal Australian Air Force aircraft.
- Tell the truth! They were not Royal Australian Air Force aircraft. They were charter aircraft.
- All right. I am taking what the Minister for the Army said. He said that Royal Australian Air Force aircraft were made available on charter to the New South Wales Government.
- No. The New South Wales Government made application to the Air Force because it could not get aircraft from civil sources, and the Air Force got them on charter for the New South Wales Government.

- All right. Let us examine the matter. The Minister for the Army then said that any charges imposed were imposed by the New South Wales Government. What the New South Wales Government did was merely to charge sufficient to cover the cost of it, because that Government, being financially starved by the Commonwealth, and having no financial reserves to meet such a contingency, was forced to pass these costs on. 1 suggest that if the Minister for the Army thinks that there is no basis for the criticism voiced by the honorable member for Darling he should tell us who were the graziers who got free use of Royal Australian Air Force aircraft, and who were the others who had to pay for the service. If he investigates the matter, he will discover that what I am now telling him is correct, and that an arrangement was made between the honorable member for Gwydir and the Minister for Air without the knowledge of the Treasurer (Sir Arthur Fadden). That arrangement was the result of direct negotiations between the honorable member for Gwydir and the Minister for Air. It was a private arrangement, and it was made so that the honorable member for Gwydir could assist some of his particularly wealthy supporters in the electorate of Gwydir. The method employed by the Government of handing out relief to those people is wrong. As a matter of fact, I have in my office a sheaf of telegrams which I had to drive into the Treasury in order to get (he airlift extended to parts of the country where smaller men were affected. Fortunately, 1 am able to say that I obtained good results, and that after a good deal of protesting by Labour members of this Parliament, a great deal of fodder went into the properties of those particular men on whose behalf members of the Opposition made representations.

speech.para: Now let me turn to the matter about which I intended to speak. It relates to some very strange happenings in the Department of Works connected with the Department of the Interior. Not so long ago representations were made to me by a manufacturer of paint who considered that he was being unfairly treated and was being discriminated against in favour of particular paint manufacturers. I have a copy of a statement which was provided by this manufacturer to the predecessor of the present occupant of the office of Minister for the Interior, in the course of which he makes some quite alarming allegations in respect of what was happening. Let me read just one or two of those allegations. He refers to an approach which he made to Mr. Brophy, who was then the Auditor-General, placing the facts before him when he could get no satisfaction from the department. On Mr. Brophy's advice, he then had the matter placed before the Public Service Board and the Commonwealth Investigation Service, and an inquiry was made.

Let us examine what this manufacturer alleges was happening. He has made direct allegations to the effect that in the Department of Works there were men handing out orders who themselves were the proprietors of paint manufacturing firms. As a result, this company, which was tendering for the supply of paint - and, in many instances, tendering at prices lower than those accepted by the department - could get no satisfaction as to why its paints were not being used. Sometimes it was told that it was not on the approved list and that, therefore, its paints could not be used. When certain contractors to the Department of Works wanted to use this firm's paints they were suddenly advised by officers of the Department of Works that it would be in their own interests if they did not use those paints but used somebody else's paints. An investigation substantiated what this man had been saying.

He gives details of particular occasions on which he tendered, or his company tendered, at a lower price than that which was accepted, and he refers to an order which was placed with his firm but which, before he could fulfil it, was actually transferred to somebody else. Then it was discovered that the man who was handling the orders was not only interested in a paint manufacturing firm but also was the sole proprietor of it, and that he had been the registered proprietor of this firm in 1949.
Let me examine what the Minister has had to say and the admissions that he has made. This is what he said in a communication to me on the 18th July last: -

quote.para: Some years ago-

speech.para: And in brackets he has " 1953 ", which is not so very long ago - following receipt of information similar to that now given to you, detailed enquiries into the allegations were made by the Public Service Inspector and the Commonwealth Investigation Service. These enquiries revealed that, whilst one officer was the proprietor of a small paint retail business, which had some limited business transactions with the Sydney Branch of the Department, no evidence of malpractice could be found.
Except that he was giving the orders to his own firm, of which he was the sole proprietor! The Minister went on to say -

quote.para: This officer was subsequently transferred to another section of the Department not in any way associated with purchasing or ordering, and he relinquished his interest in the firm concerned. One other person was found, after retirement from the Public Service, to have had a similar interest during at least the latter portion of his service. That such a thing could happen, of course is a matter for extreme concern. I have, therefore, expressed my views on the subject in no uncertain terms, both to my Department and to the Public Service Board, and have given such instructions as will prevent any recurrence. Meantime, results of the most thorough investigation are such as to indicate with certainty that such practices do not now exist in the Department.

speech.para: I followed the matter up and asked the Minister whether he would make these reports available to me as a member of this Parliament, because I wanted to ascertain what their own investigation had discovered concerning the situation of this department, and this is what the Minister wrote to me on the 9th of this month -

quote.para: I have for acknowledgment your letter of July 30th, in which you request access to the reports of the Public Service Inspector and of the Commonwealth Investigation Service covering investigations into the associations of certain officers of the Department of Works with the paint business. In view of the fact that adequate steps have been taken to prevent a recurrence of what is admittedly an unsatisfactory position I do not propose to depart from the general practice of preserving the confidential nature of such reports.

talk.start.para: - Order! The honorable gentleman's time has expired.

quote.para: That the honorable member for East Sydney (Mr. Ward), be granted an extension of time.

division.header.para: The House divided. (Mr. Speaker - Hon. John McLeay.)

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: .- I direct attention to the difficult problem of import licences in relation to a particular industry in Western Australia. Honorable members all know that import licences are a necessary evil.
- They are an evil, all right.

- The difficulty in administering them is also well known. I do not want it to be thought that I am critical of the very difficult job that the Department of Trade has in making decisions to allot or withhold import licences, but it seems to me that we must be perpetually on our guard to ensure that where genera] principles are established in regard to the allocation of import licences, they are clearly understood and observed in such a way that no arbitrary decision will be made as between one person and another or between one group of interests and another group of interests. One of the risks we run in the operation of such a control is the typical bureaucratic attitude which is developing within the department. Responsible officers have to refuse a great many requests, and they tend to develop an attitude of mind which leads them to produce an argument or use a phrase which they consider is generally good or unanswerable.

speech.para: I direct the attention of the House to such odd practices occurring as when a group of importers approaches the department for a licence they are told that, upon an examination of local resources, it is found that the particular requirements of Australia can be supplied from within the country and, consequently, the granting of an import licence is not justified. But when local producers approach the department and point out that they can save the Government a considerable sum in foreign exchange by supplying the Australian market, and that the import licences relating to a certain industry should therefore be cut down, the department says that import licence control is not intended to operate for the protection of local industry. Those two attitudes are clearly contradictory. If we have, as a primary objective, the saving of foreign exchange, that is plain enough, but we must realize that wherever imports are restricted, some form of local supply to the market is inevitably protected. That must be faced as a necessary consequence.

My remarks have particular reference to the timber industry in Western Australia, and the supply of timber to the market in South Australia. The Western Australian timber industry was compelled, at one stage, to supply karri and jarrah for the South Australian market to the degree that it was forbidden to export, and at that point Western Australia lost valuable export markets. At the present time, there is a recession in the building industry in Western Australia, but the timber suppliers find that South Australia has been placed in a preferential position in regard to the cutting of import quotas of Malayan hardwood and American oregon. Whereas States like New South Wales and Victoria have had their quotas reduced by 20 per cent, and 15 per cent, respectively, the South Australian quota has been reduced by only 10 per cent. Western Australia has available, not at competitive prices but at lower prices, supplies of karri suitable for all the purposes for which these other timbers are required in South Australia. The department says, firstly, that it does not intend to operate as a protector of Australian industry, but if the Government wishes to save foreign exchange, here is a local source of supply which is competitive. . Secondly,, the department argues, that the Tariff Board dealt with the subject some years ago, and decided that it did not intend to protect the Western Australian industry. It must be remembered, however, that when that Tariff Board decision was made there was a building boom in progress, and there was not a surplus of timber in Western Australia to meet South Australia's requirements. The department says, thirdly, that South Australian merchants have a preference for American

Oregon. Even though the prices are competitive and the quality of Western Australian timbers is proved to be equally suitable, of course the South Australian merchants express a preference for a commodity for which they have an import licence.

It is well known to-day that, regardless of the quality of imports, as long as people have a licence and a quota they stick to them. The Western Australian building industry is now suffering a recession.I shall not deal with the causes of it. It is certain, however, that the Commonwealth will be asked to help the Western Australian industry. In my electorate, timber mills are being forced to reduce their staffs and cut down their activities because there is no market for the timber. The attitude of some departmental officials seems to be rather stupid in the circumstances when Government policy is to save foreign exchange wherever possible. We want to create employment and supply requirements from local resources as far as possible.

There seems to be no real reason why South Australia, which has had tremendous benefits at the expense of the Western Australian export trade, should receive such preferential treatment in this matter. One is almost inclined to think that the official administering this matter in the Department of Trade is a South Australian.

talk.start.para: . - I should not have spoken on this matter to-night, but in my opinion the honorable member for Forrest (Mr. Freeth) is playing the game at a very low level in putting forward such an argument as we have just heard. In South Australia the building industry, at times, has tried without success, to obtain jarrah from Western Australia. When the honorable member talks about preferential treatment in allowing South Australia to import Oregon, either he has a poor idea of what type of timber is required in the building industry in South Australia or he is just trying to put up something as an election stunt. In South Australia, Oregon stands out on its own as a timber for roofing purposes. I have had a lot to do with the different timbers through the years, and I do know that the Oregon, which is imported into South Australia, meets the needs of that State to a great extent. We do not use Oregon for flooring joists and we will not use karri near the ground. The honorable member knows that it is not suitable for such use, but we use jarrah. I like jarrah very much for floor joists, stumps, or other purposes for which timber has to be used near the ground. We are anxious to get it. But it is wrong to say that our oregon imports are injuring the industry of Western Australia. I do not think for a moment that we should try to make one State use a particular timber from another State when it is not as suitable as the timber that can be obtained from overseas, such as oregon.

speech.para: I hope that the Department of Customs and Excise will not take too much notice of what the honorable member has said in connexion with that import licence. For very many years, we in South Australia found that if we wanted jarrah from Western Australia, we were not able to get it because that State was sending shiploads of it overseas as sleepers. The sale of jarrah to other countries augments our overseas funds.

talk.start.para: - You cut out our markets by banning exports.
- We have not cut out your markets in South Australia.
- You importoregon.

- I ask the honorable member whether he would put jarrah in a roof in preference to oregon. No! Of course, the honorable member would not do so. Jarrah may be used in roofs in Western Australia because it is cheaper than other timber.
- You do not know what the South Australian Housing Commission says.

- I do know what the South Australian Housing Commission says. I know that if the commission considers that jar rah is better than Oregon for housing purposes, it will use jarrah. But, for years, jarrah has been an impossible price in South Australia, and we have found it impossible to get the quantities required. I want jarrah and Australian material generally to be used wherever possible, but 1 do not want any honorable member to tell South Australia that it must use jarrah when Oregon is more suitable for roofing purposes and we desire to use it. We do not use Oregon, as I said before, for the under parts of houses. We use it only for the upright parts. We in South Australia are in the unfortunate position that we have no mountain ash, as they have in Victoria, which they can use for their roofing timbers. In South Australia, apart from pinus, which is used extensively for flooring, we have very little other building timber. Western Australia is fortunate; it has a variety of timbers. Queensland, Victoria and New South Wales all have good types of timber. I doubt very much whether the plea that has been made by the honorable member on behalf of Western Australia is justified regarding the supply of roofing timbers in South Australia.

talker.role: Minister for the Interior and Minister for Works
talker.name: FAIRHALL, Allen
Mr FAIRHALL

talk.start.para: . - 1 want to deal shortly with the .remarks that the honorable member for East Sydney (Mr. Ward) has made to-night. This is not the first occasion on which he has raised this complaint, and it has been dealt with before. But in view of the honorable gentleman's propensity for finding a discordant note in the symphony and coming back to play on it as often as possible, one expects this to keep coming up. I propose to give the House and the honorable member quite a simple explanation. Indeed, he has read it to-night in the form of my letter.

speech.para: This is the background of the matter. In 1949, a paint firm in Sydney sought the entry of its product to the approved list of paints used by the Department of Works. When told that his paint would have to undergo a test, the gentleman concerned said that he was more interested in selling paints than he was in undergoing tests. But the department is rather jealous of the quality of the paints which it uses on its public works jobs, and we insisted that these particular items should be tested to the specifications.

The point raised by the honorable gentleman is quite right - that we had in the * Department of Works in Sydney a gentleman who, under the provisions of the Public Service Act, had secured approval to engage in employment outside his public service employment. The whole procedure of public servants being employed outside their own calling is not one- which has any attraction for me.

Obviously, there was laxity as far as the Public Service inspector was concerned in not ascertaining the fact that this gentleman proposed to engage in the paint industry when, in fact, he was a buyer of paints for the Department of Works. But immediately upon the complaint being made by this particular manufacturer, who had apparently lost the orders on the quality of his paints and not on the fact that he had been undermined by the buyer, the whole matter was investigated most searchingly. No evidence appeared that this paint manufacturer had lost any order or had been inconvenienced by the fact that this particular officer was in the paint business. Nevertheless, some very harsh words were said to the officers in the department and to the Public Service inspector concerned, and such steps have been taken as will prevent a recurrence of this sort of thing.

talk.start.para: - Was he not buying from his own firm? What happened to him?
- He was transferred to other employment.
- But he was buying paint from his own firm, of which he was the sole proprietor.

- No. There was no evidence of that. When the honorable member asks that I should disclose the whole of the Public Service inspector's investigation and report into this matter, he well knows that that is not a procedure which has ever been followed in this House. I do not imagine that, the honorable member will ever be satisfied by anybody's undertaking, since his own have always been so doubtful, but I offer to him the undertaking that this matter has been looked at with extreme care. Steps have been taken to prevent a repetition. I have no intention of offering the honorable gentleman the details of the report.

. - I want to refer to a matter which I brought up on the motion for the adjournment of the House at the end of the last sessional period. I referred to the introduction of television and the sales of television sets on the Australian market. 1 said on that occasion that I had been informed that a certain manufacturer of television sets in Australia had departed from the recognized standard laid down by the Australian Broadcasting Control Board. During my speech, the Minister for the Interior (Mr. Fairhall), I think, and also the Postmaster-General (Mr. Davidson), by way of interjection, intimated that they would have the matter looked into.
- They have, too.

- The matter has been looked into, and the Postmaster-General has issued two statements warning the public about the possibility of purchasing sets which have not complied with the standards laid down by the Australian Broadcasting Control Board. To the extent that the Minister's warnings have served to save people the expense of buying sets that are not up to the standard we require in this country, the warnings have done incalculable good. I know that many people had ordered these sets about which I complain. I now name the sets concerned as the " Admiral " television sets, which are made by an American firm, from American parts, and most of which are assembled in Australia. Many of the orders put in for " Admiral " sets were cancelled after the Minister's explanation had been made to the public.

speech.para: I realize that, for legal reasons - damages and the like - he was not able to name in a public statement the company that I know he had in mind. That is a pity. But if it is not possible for him to name the company or companies which are manufacturing television sets that do not comply with the standards laid down by the Australian Broadcasting Control Board, perhaps he will be able to overcome the difficulty by naming those that do comply with those standards. If that cannot be done for the same reason as I indicated a moment ago - because by inference leaving a person out, perhaps, could in law be deemed to be an attack on him or damaging to him - then I think the Minister ought to give serious consideration to the issuing of some standards certificate that could be issued by the Australian Broadcasting Control Board only in respect of television sets that do comply with the standards laid down by the board.

The " Admiral " television set is very attractive, lt is the kind of set which a person, not knowing anything about television - and few people in Australia do - would buy, because it is a much more attractive set in its outside appearance than are many others. It is the kind of set that any woman would prefer if she were given the job of selecting a television set for the home. She would come home laden with this useless " Admiral " set which, when television gets under way properly, will not give the proper reception that we in this country consider to be a minimum requirement. I understand, too, that this Government, or the Minister for Customs and Excise (Mr. Osborne) has granted to the " Admiral " company import licences to bring into this country parts for the assembling of these " Admiral " sets, and I understand that these parts are being brought in to the value of thousands of dollars. If my information is correct and the figure given to me is correct, 100,000 dollars' worth of parts are being brought into the country; but the parts that are being brought in under the licence that has been issued to the " Admiral " company have been rejected by the American standards committee. They are no longer accepted in America and as they, therefore, represent surplus, they are being sent to this country because it is new insofar as television is concerned and in the hope of catching us before we realize how useless they really are.

The whole trouble is that a television set costs between £200 and £300 and up to £400, and I think it is a tragedy that any person, whether he be rich or poor, but more so if he be a poor person, because he can ill afford to lose the money, should have to invest a sum of money ranging from £200 to £400 in a set which may prove to be, if not useless, then by comparison with proper standard sets, very inferior. The Minister should take some steps now, perhaps by following me and confirming, or otherwise, what I have said about the " Admiral " set, to give a further warning to the public, as he has done twice already, against buying these inferior sets. This is a most important matter and I hope the public will be warned against buying sets of such inferior quality.

talk.start.para: .- I rise to support the submission made by the honorable member for Forrest (Mr. Freeth) in connexion with the export of timber from the south-west of Western Australia. I am afraid that the honorable member for Port Adelaide (Mr. Thompson), when he replied to the honorable member for Forrest, was quite unaware of some of the statements that have been made by the State Housing Trust in South Australia, which, for some time, has held quite a different opinion from that held by the honorable member for Port Adelaide. Even as far back as May, 1949, the State Housing Trust stated that South Australia had come to regard karri very highly as a constructional timber for house building. Since about 1941 the trust has constantly specified this timber for almost all constructional purposes and both the trust and its builders have come to regard karri as eminently suitable for this purpose. Then, in 1956, the State Housing Authority in South Australia stated -

quote.para: It has been alleged from time to time that the State Housing Trust is not seriously interested in the purchase of karri. This is a matter of great astonishment as the State Housing Trust specification has always been written naming karri as the scantling timber.

speech.para: The Department of Trade's refusal of the request of the association to impose some sort of restriction upon the import of oregon was based upon a Tariff Board report of 1954. The report stated that because the timber industry in Western Australia had not succeeded in inducing people in that State to use a greater quantity of karri timber it had difficulty in disposing of the surplus of karri to other States. Figures will prove that that is not quite the fact, because in 1952-53 the karri exports amounted to 17,329,368 super, feet whilst the local usage was 21,507,612 super, feet. In 1953-54, the export figure was 12,408,432 super, feet, a drop of 5,000,000 super, feet, but the local usage increased by 5,000,000 super, feet to 26,010,540 super, feet. In 1954-55, exports dropped another 1,000,000 to 11,897,676 super, feet whilst local usage went up to 27,644,832 super, feet. So, it is quite obvious that the State was absorbing to its fullest capacity the amount of karri that could be used in the building and other industries.

The honorable member for Port Adelaide also stated that he doubted whether jarrah was a useful timber for building purposes, but tests carried out by the requisite authorities, the standards associations in Australia and America, have proved that in all cases karri is well in front of the softwoods of America. There is only one great advantage in the use of softwoods for building purposes and that is the advantage to the men who are. doing the construction. As all honorable members know, it is easier to drive a nail into a piece of Oregon, or Malayan softwood, or to saw that same wood, than it is to treat karri for building purposes. However, it should be borne in mind that those who are handling this timber would be doing the men engaged in the timber industry in Western Australia a great service if they could express a preference to use karri for building purposes in South Australia. At the present time, the Western Australian timber industry is battling against severe odds. It is little realized that in the mere matter of freight rates by sea Western Australian timber is at a disadvantage when compared with timber brought from America or Malaya. For example, the freight cost of timber from Malaya to Adelaide is only 33s. per 100 super, feet compared with 34s. lOd. per 100 super, feet from Bunbury, in our south-west, to Adelaide. If a comparison of the distances is made it will be found that it is a great disadvantage because of this high freight rate due to shipping and wharf charges. Nevertheless, karri can be landed in South Australia at a competitive price. The average price for Oregon landed at Port Adelaide is 155s. 6d. per 100 super, feet. For Malayan timber the price is 134s., for Western Australian jarrah the price is 144s. and for Western Australian karri 132s.

So, it will be seen that the timber merchants of Western Australia can compete in every way. They have a competitive price and timber whose standards have been judged better than those of other softwoods. The only disadvantage that karri has is its hardness. However, it has been proved to have greater strength for beams and other uses than have any of the imported timbers. If the recent 1st luly figures, as mentioned by the honorable member for Forrest, of a 20 per cent. cut in one State, 15 per cent. in another and 10 per cent. in South Australia, had been made uniform up to 20 per cent., that would have covered all these difficulties, and by that very stroke would have saved the Commonwealth some £.750,000 in dollar exchange, which, at this stage of our history, is most important.

Now, there is the other point about the restriction of trade that was placed upon the Western Australian timber merchants during the war. That carried on right up till 1950 when the Commonwealth Timber Controller instructed the export associations to supply the South Australian market with quantities which precluded them from exporting when they had the export market. During that time they were limited in the amount they were allowed to send overseas. So, by adopting the suggestion made by the honorable member for Forrest, supported by myself, many difficulties would be overcome. First of all, we would show some consideration for the Western Australian Government that has been talked about. It would relieve the position over there. Secondly, it would conserve the dollar exchange merely by a restriction of an import of timber for which there seems to be no need in South Australia except that some people have established quotas and they do not like to lose them. To all intents and purposes, as the evidence submitted by the State Housing Trust shows, the timber is ideally suited, the cost is satisfactory, and its use for housing purposes will encourage the development of Western Australia and ensure that an industry that is doing fairly well at present will not sink back, to the detriment of a lot of people in the State of Western Australia.

talk.start.para: . - I rise only for the purpose of explaining the position of the Government in regard to the system of central import licensing. At the outset I may state that the Government has a thorough appreciation of the point of view put forward by the honorable member for Perth (Mr. Chaney) and the honorable member for Forrest (Mr. Freeth). The Government is well aware of the fact that at present, because of a change in conditions in Western Australia, there has been a tendency for some unemployment to occur. For that reason the Government fully appreciates the proposition put forward by the two honorable members, that everything should be done to protect Western Australian industries, and, in particular, to encourage the sale of karri and jarrah timber. I can give my personal assurance to the two honorable gentlemen that the Government has, within recent weeks, given this matter most careful attention, and is now ascertaining what can be done to give the help that the honorable members have asked for.

speech.para: I may say, in reply to the honorable member for Forrest, that there is one primary purpose of the import licensing system, and that is to protect ourLondon funds and our international trade balance. Of course, when we are protecting those funds and that balance, we must incidentally exercise a protective influence on some Australian industries, by our very action in restricting imports. In following our policy we have two objectives in mind. The first is to ensure that the most efficient and effective use shall be made of Australian resources. The second is to ensure that in this period of rising costs and prices we do not impose too great a strain on Australian industry, and so drive up costs and prices to a higher level than is in fact necessary. I know, from looking at the file containing the application by the Western Australian forestry interests, that when the problem of the sale of jarrah and karri was dealt with both of the considerations that I have just mentioned were given careful attention. I can give honorable members a further assurance that when the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade, the honorable member for Darling Downs (Mr. Swartz), was in Western Australia recently, he interviewed the Jarrah Export Committee, and gave the committee an assurance that this problem would be considered as soon as he returned to Canberra. It is now being considered, and I can give my colleagues from Forrest and Perth the assurance that if something effective can be done it will be done. I do not want to be hypocritical about this matter, and so I must tell the honorable members that I do not hold out very positive hopes that they will obtain all the benefits that they may seek. I do say, however, that the whole problem is now being considered, and the department will come to a decision on the basis of the principles that 1 have just stated. I repeat that my colleague, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade, has spoken to the Jarrah Export Committee on this matter, and I think that the members of that committee know exactly what the position is.

talk.start.para: . - I crave the indulgence of the House to make some comments in reply to remarks made by the honorable member for Hindmarsh (Mr. Clyde Cameron), on a motion for the adjournment of the House towards the end of the last sessional period, and again to-night. I refer to the honorable member's remarks concerning the standard of television sets being offered to the public by certain companies. The Government fully realizes that in order to ensure that the reception of television shall be as favorable as possible, it is desirable that the sets offered to the public should all be of a quality and a kind which will present the best image. If that is so, purchasers will be able to receive programmes right from the start of television broadcasting, and that in turn will react favorably on the development of television. At the same time I remind honorable members that there is nothing in the act at present that empowers the Government or the Australian Broadcasting Control Board, acting on behalf of the Government, to prohibit the sale of any receiver.
- What about import licences?

- 1 shall deal with that aspect of the matter in a few minutes. Nevertheless, the Australian Broadcasting Control Board had conferences with manufacturers, through the medium of the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, to ensure, by co-operation rather than by coercion, that the receivers offered to the public would be of the quality desired. The board arranged with the manufacturers to have certain definite standards adopted in the manufacture of sets in Australia. The main feature of those standards is that the sets should be designed to operate on an intermediate frequency of 30.5 megacycles for sound, and 36 megacycles for vision. The object of that provision is to remove the possibility of interference from other users of the spectrum on other frequencies. Wc have found that the manufacturers, in the main, have abided by the standards agreed on with the Australian Broadcasting Control Board, but that the particular company named by the honorable member for Hindmarsh is offering a set that does not use the intermediate frequencies laid down. lt is using an intermediate frequency for both sound and vision, which could result in interference from the use of that frequency by other commercial people and by amateurs.

speech.para: I investigated this matter immediately after the honorable member had raised it in the House. I should say also at this stage that I received a letter at the same time from the honorable member for Maribyrnong (Mr. Stokes), dealing with the same subject. At that time I found that the Wireless Institute of Australia, the members of which are amateur operators, had submitted representations to the board to the effect that the use of this intermediate frequency in the set in question would result in poor vision, and that they, the amateurs, would be likely to be blamed. They also submitted that the Government might be forced to take some action to alter the frequencies used by the amateurs. The board, on my instructions, carried out a series of tests of the sets in question. Although some further tests have still to be made, the investigations have proceeded to the point where the board can tell me that there can be no question of the technical excellence of the set - I say that because I am trying to put the position factually and fairly - but that certain interference can arise by the use, not only by amateurs but also by other commercial people, of the frequency that these sets are using, and that it is, therefore, undesirable that people should purchase this receiver if they want good reception.

As I stated previously, the Government has no authority to ban the sale of such a set, but I took the action which seemed to me to be best in the circumstances. 1 issued two statements, one of which indicated the standards which people should look for in the receivers that they purchased if they wanted good reception. Only the intermediate frequencies that would give good reception were mentioned, and purchasers were advised not to buy sets that did not operate on those frequencies. An undertaking was given, both in a press statement and by a letter to the Wireless Institute of Australia, that if receivers were sold which were subject to interference as a result of the operations of amateurs, the Government would not, at any time, consider interfering with the amateurs' band. In other words, their right would be preserved. That is the present position, except in regard to import licences, which come under the jurisdiction of my colleague, the Minister for Trade (Mr. McEwen). As a result of the action that he took after the discussion I had with him, the importation of these particular components has been stopped, and will not be resumed.

The honorable member suggested that 1 might be prepared, in addition to what I have already done, to provide for some sort of a sticker or badge to be put on a set, to the effect that it conformed to the standards of the board. At present, I am not prepared to take that action, because I think there is a limit to what the Government should do in wet-nursing the public. That is putting it quite plainly. The warning I have given is perfectly plain. I know that it has been widely publicized in both Sydney and Melbourne, where the sets are being sold, and I also know from the trade that it has warned people of the position that exists. It is now up tor the people to exercise their own discretion. I said a few minutes ago that these matters were still under consideration. The honorable member and others can judge from the action that I have already taken that, in the event of further action becoming necessary, I. will take it.

talk.start.para: - 1 have listened with interest to this discussion regarding certain television sets that are to-day on the market. Whilst it is quite true that the Postmaster-General (Mr. Davidson) did make a statement that indicated to the public that some sets on the market did not comply with the standards which the commission considered desirable, I am convinced that the general public are not yet sufficiently informed to be able to protect themselves. The plain fact is that in the City of Melbourne alone there are on sale in the shops very large numbers of the set in question, and their sale is being actively pushed. I am convinced, also, that there is a danger that some of the press organs of this country may be interested in this particular set, and that the press may not give the publicity to the matter that it might otherwise give in helping to warn the public not to purchase the set. It is deplorable and unfortunate that some enterprises might lose money over this matter, but surely, after all, this Government and this Parliament have a responsibility to protect the people, not partially, but wholly. I say quite frankly, as one who, up to the present moment, has not been vitally interested, and is not likely to become vitally interested in the purchase of a television set, that until I met the honorable member for Hindmarsh (Mr. Clyde Cameron) here the other day, I did not know what set the Postmaster-General was warning the people against purchasing. I had no conception that it was a set named the " Admiral ". I knew that reputable shops in Melbourne-
- The honorable member could have asked the shopkeepers about the number of frequencies.

- Does the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr. McMahon) believe that a prospective customer should have to ask a shopkeeper about all of the things that the Postmaster-General considers to be necessary?
- I give the honorable member for Lalor credit for possessing a little common sense.
- It is quite obvious that the Minister is trying to shelter somebody.
- I am trying to protect the honorable member himself.

speech.para: Motion (by Sir Eric Harrison) put -

quote.para: That the question be now put

division.header.para: The House divided. (Mr. Speaker - Hon. John McLeay.)

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

division.para: Original question resolved in the affirmative.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated: -

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice -

item.para: Is it Treasury practice to allot funds to departments up to 30th June each year?
Is it a fact that, thereafter, departments have no knowledge of funds to be allotted until the budget is presented in September or October of the next financial year?
Does the apparent over-estimate of some departments arise from this hiatus?
Is this the explanation of the apparent failure to spend £9,000,000 out of the £50,000,000 vote for the Department of Air?

Is it a fact that, especially in the departments connected with defence, this system is causing confusion and late ordering of equipment and that, in the face of representation, the Treasury has not altered its system?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows: -

item.para: The funds for expenditure are appropriated by Parliament. Every appropriation made out of the Consolidated Revenue Fund for the services of a financial year lapses at the close of that year.

As a general rule, departments are aware in July or August of each year of the amounts which have been approved by the Government for submission to Parliament. Funds which are required for expenditure prior to the passing of the annual Appropriation Acts are appropriated by Supply Acts which are assented to prior to the commencement of the financial year.

The effects of the present parliamentary procedures are discussed at some length in the Eighteenth Report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and will be referred to in the Treasury minute to be submitted on that report.

Of the £9,000,000 under spent out of the £58,000,000 voted for the Department of Air in 1954-55, the department advises that £7,000,000 related to equipment and stores which were expected, on advices received from the suppliers, both local and overseas, to be delivered and paid for within the financial year. Deliveries were not, however, made as expected. Of the balance, £1,200,000 was in respect of works, for which the programme was reduced because of conditions then prevailing in the building and construction industry.

Nothing in the existing Treasury procedures causes confusion or late ordering of equipment; this matter will also be discussed in the Treasury minute on the Eighteenth Report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Labour and National Service, upon notice -

item.para: Will he furnish (a) a comprehensive statement relating to the existing position of unemployment and employment, &c., within the area with which the Wollongong office of the Commonwealth Employment Service is concerned and (b) comparative figures for the past two years?

Will he include, in particular - (a) the number of (i) adult males, (ii) adult females, and (iii) juveniles registered as unemployed; (b) the number of (i) males and (ii) females registered as unemployed who are in receipt of social service benefits, showing the age groups in which they are classified; (c) the total number of registered vacant positions; (d) the classifications of these vacancies, and the number in each classification, in relation to the employment of (i) adult males, (ii) adult females, (iii) juveniles, and (iv) apprentices, indicating the numbers required in respective trades; (e) what age limits are imposed by employers ' seeking labour to fill vacancies for (i) adult males and (ii) adult females?

talk.start.para: - As I was unable to obtain the details before the House went into recess, I provided the honorable member with this information by letter on 26th June last.
